mauramagpie: Thank you for sharing all this. It will definitely help others. I am also bipolar, but I wasn’t diagnosed until I was 49 years old. I avoided getting help, even though I had struggled with depression and gone crazy during manic phases since my teens. I can look back over the years (I’m 62 now) and see that, every time my life went off the rails, it started with a manic episode. Taking a mood stabilizer and antidepressant changed my life, too, and I have accepted that I will need to take them for the rest of my life. I have also been learning that there is no need to feel shame about being bipolar. I was born that way, just as I was born with red hair. My genetic makeup included bipolar condition, and I can’t change that. But what I can do is keep seeing my psychiatrist, going to therapy, and taking my medications. 🤗❤️

immiyk: Jammies are great, yes! But you are awesome for accepting. I finally accepted it when I was hiding and crying in my shower right after I got engaged to a wonderful man who didn’t deserve to have to even witness my chaotic misery. I, like you, always took ONE thing since high school... and it never quite clicked until I was in a deep, dark, black hole living with my soon to be husband. I need to pull my life together bc I am no longer alone all of the time. That balance finally came when I admitted... it was a mood disorder and not just depression. I got my double dose now but, I don’t kid myself, there will always be that uncertainty when having to leave the house in the morning, the forced smile at the even you drag your ass out of the house for, even though you have come up with every excuse in the book to stay home. joanne.louisa: These words resonate so strongly with me. I went back on medication a few months ago after a long time off them - being newly divorced and newly unemployed wasn't a good enough excuse for me to explain why I had "allowed" the anxiety to take a hold again. I felt so defeated, so embarrassed, so disappointed in myself. But it's a fallacy we sell to ourselves isn't it? That we can somehow control it, that's it's nothing more than a quirk of our personality and we should be able to get the f*** over it. I have never felt more relief, or freedom than when I finally started allowing myself to acknowledge that it was there, and I was going to have to learn to live at peace with it. Thank you so much for sharing, and allowing the rest of us a platform to respond in kind, we are stronger together 😉. Much love to you Jen! ❤️

abrockwood: I love reading your posts about this. This is me exactly. So many different cocktails with different doctors. Then I finally found a doctor that figured it out with me. agbrott: 💪💪💪. My story is somewhat similar. I was diagnosed at 10 and found the right meds straight away but at 22 I stopped taking my meds after forgetting to refill a prescription. I was fine and thought I had grown out of it. (Later I realized I was not my balanced healthy self) but it really hit me after some major life changes and moving cross country for a time that my mental health TANKED. I cried, didn’t eat, couldn’t sleep, among many other physical symptoms brought on. I wanted to be my strong healthy vibrant self again. That was 2yrs ago and I’m back on my meds, started seeing my doctor again, and I’ve grown from my experience. It’s always there, it’s part of who I am and those dark days make us stronger. theslyestfox: You are an inspiration for so many. Sometimes people need meds to get them through a rough patch, and sometimes brain chemistry just necessitates them, and neither are anything to be ashamed of. For so so long men had all the power, so the traditional male “be a man” qualities of sucking it up and being “strong” meant people didn’t want to reach out for help via emotional support, talking about mental health or seeing mental health professionals and taking medication. And it hurts everyone of every gender. As we dismantle the patriarchy, everyone is now beginning to see that needing help and seeking it doesn’t make us weak — it makes us so much stronger. 💪 when we all are able to talk about our emotions, seek support, see a therapist (etc) without shame, find what medication works etc it helps everyone. Thank you for being open and authentic and honest and making a once taboo subject many people are afraid to talk about, a journey to share. You are truly an inspiration.

jesbland: Love this. Prayers for you and your health! I was started with Prozac too, no good for me. jessabtame: Right there with you. ❤I have struggled with anxiety and deppresion since a young child, but I didn't start meds till I was in high school. I went through atleast 5 anti deppresion/anti anxiety meds mixed in a cocktail with others. I would max out on the dose and still feel wrong. On again off again, telling myself I could manage alone, or just with therapy. Finally at 35 (now 39) a doctor said lets try some bi-polar meds. Bam. That was it. I have my moments and weeks where things are hard, but nothing like in the past. I came to terms with the fact that meds are something I am just going to have to accept as part of my life. It's a hard pill to swallow sometimes (no pun intended). 😉 You have been doing some great soul searching to live in the light. You don't know me, but man am I proud of you. maryannsbetter: I was diagnosed with Bipolar II earlier this year, after years of trying antidepressants and then of avoiding them, going to psychiatrists and therapist and then avoiding them too. bethanndyer: Thanks for sharing so publicly! I have bipolar as well. Lamotrigine totally changed my life for the better.
